title: Four Perspectives on the US-China Rivalry Thesis

perspectives.name: Pentagon Strategist
perspectives.role: Former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, Indo-Pacific Affairs, 20 years in defense policy
perspectives.initial_position: The carrier math in this thesis is classified-level accurate and public-level alarming. People hear '11 carrier strike groups' and assume overwhelming naval power. The reality: at any given time, 3-4 are deployable, 3-4 are in maintenance, and 3-4 are in training cycles. Maintaining credible deterrence in the Pacific while honoring commitments in the Mediterranean, Gulf, and Atlantic is a shell game we've been losing since 2018. The thesis correctly identifies that China doesn't need to fight us—it just needs to ensure we're busy everywhere else while the window of vulnerability on Taiwan remains open. Every crisis in the Middle East, every commitment in Europe, is a strategic gift to Beijing.
key_threats: The carrier gap is real and widening. The Ford-class program is $13B per ship and 3 years behind schedule. China is commissioning carriers faster than we can maintain ours. By 2030, the PLA Navy will have 400+ ships to our 290. Quantity has a quality of its own in naval warfare—especially when the fight is 6,000 miles from your shipyards and 100 miles from theirs.

Anti-ship ballistic missiles (DF-21D, DF-26) have changed the calculus. The 'carrier killer' creates a 1,500km exclusion zone around China's coast where our carriers operate at unacceptable risk. We've never fought a peer adversary with precision-guided anti-ship weapons. Our carrier doctrine was developed against Soviet submarines, not ballistic missile volleys.

The Taiwan scenario isn't hypothetical planning—it's active preparation. PLA exercises increasingly rehearse blockade and amphibious assault scenarios. Xi has publicly tied his legacy to reunification. The 2027 timeline (PLA centenary) is a forcing function. If Xi assesses that the US is sufficiently distracted, the calculation for action changes from 'if' to 'when.'
key_moves: Accelerate distributed maritime operations—smaller, more numerous, more survivable platforms instead of concentrating capability in 6,000-sailor carriers. Unmanned surface vessels, long-range anti-ship missiles, and submarine-launched weapons can project power without the vulnerability of a carrier strike group.

Pre-position munitions and logistics in the first island chain. Japan, the Philippines, Australia, and Guam need ammunition stockpiles sufficient for a 30-day high-intensity conflict. Current stockpiles are measured in days. The logistics of resupply across 6,000 miles of contested ocean make pre-positioning essential.

Strategic clarity on Taiwan. Ambiguity served us when China was weak. Now it creates instability—Beijing might miscalculate that we won't respond, or that our response will be limited. Clear deterrence (explicit commitment to defend Taiwan) is the highest-probability path to avoiding conflict.
blind_spots: I'm so focused on military capability that I underweight the economic instrument. China's leverage isn't just military—it's economic interdependence. If conflict erupts, semiconductor supply collapses, and the global economy enters a depression that makes 2008 look mild. This economic mutually assured destruction might be a more effective deterrent than any number of carriers.

The assumption that Taiwan is the central flashpoint might blind us to other scenarios. South China Sea escalation, a Korea crisis, or even a cyber-first conflict could trigger confrontation without anyone making a deliberate decision about Taiwan. We're planning for the scenario we can see while the actual crisis might come from a direction we're not watching.
perspectives.revised_position: The thesis is correct in its core strategic logic: the carrier math constrains every US commitment, and China's strategy is to exploit that constraint without fighting. My revised assessment is more urgent: the window of maximum risk is 2026-2030, when PLA modernization is mature but US distributed capabilities haven't yet deployed. The 11 carrier / 3-4 deployable math means we can't simultaneously deter China in the Pacific, support Ukraine-adjacent operations in Europe, and maintain presence in the Middle East. Something has to give, and the thesis correctly identifies that the trade-off is being made—mostly in China's favor—without public acknowledgment. The defense spending implications are $50-100B annually above current budgets to close the gap. That money is coming; the question is whether it comes before or after a crisis forces it.

perspectives.name: Semiconductor Executive
perspectives.role: VP of Strategy at a major chipmaker, 15 years in semiconductor supply chain
perspectives.initial_position: Taiwan is the most dangerous place on earth precisely because of what I do for a living. TSMC makes 60%+ of the world's advanced semiconductors. If Taiwan's production is disrupted—through conflict, blockade, or even credible threat—every phone, car, server, weapons system, and medical device on the planet faces a supply crisis that makes COVID look manageable. The US-China rivalry isn't about ideology or territory—it's about who controls the $600B semiconductor supply chain. And right now, we all depend on an island 100 miles from hostile shores.
key_threats: TSMC concentration risk is existential for the global economy. N3 and N2 process nodes exist only in Hsinchu, Taiwan. No amount of fab construction in Arizona, Japan, or Germany replicates this capability for 5-7 years minimum. A 6-month disruption to TSMC would cause a global recession. A permanent disruption would reshape the world economy.

Export controls are a double-edged sword. Restricting China's access to advanced chips and equipment slows their progress but also motivates massive domestic investment. Huawei's Mate 60 Pro with a SMIC-fabricated 7nm chip showed that China is closer to self-sufficiency than we assumed. Every escalation in export controls accelerates China's motivation to develop alternatives.

The talent war is the real bottleneck. Advanced semiconductor manufacturing requires 10,000+ engineers with rare expertise. The US has maybe 5,000 qualified engineers for leading-edge fabs. TSMC Arizona is struggling to staff and has had to import Taiwanese engineers. You can build a fab in 3 years. You can't train an engineer in less than 7.
key_moves: Geographic diversification of leading-edge production is an absolute necessity—even at massive cost and efficiency loss. TSMC Arizona, Samsung Texas, Intel Ohio, and Rapidus Japan are all strategically critical even if they never match Taiwan economics. The insurance premium is worth paying.

Stockpile strategic chip inventory. Governments should maintain 6-12 month strategic semiconductor reserves similar to Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The cost ($50-100B) is trivial compared to the economic damage of a supply disruption.

Accelerate advanced packaging and chiplet technology. Advanced packaging (which Amkor does) can combine less-advanced chips into near-cutting-edge capability. This reduces the dependency on TSMC's most advanced nodes and creates geographic flexibility.
blind_spots: My industry benefits enormously from the geopolitical tension—$200B in global semiconductor subsidies in the last 3 years. I should be skeptical of my own bullishness about 'strategic necessity' because every dollar spent on geographic diversification flows to my industry. The contrarian view: AI might reduce chip intensity per unit of economic value, making the semiconductor bottleneck less critical over time.

I assume rational actors. But the Taiwan scenario includes irrational actors, miscalculation, and domestic political pressures. Xi's personal legacy and CCP legitimacy are tied to reunification in ways that don't fit neat game-theory models. The most dangerous period is one where Beijing feels it must act for internal political reasons regardless of the economic consequences.
perspectives.revised_position: The thesis is existentially correct about semiconductor supply chain vulnerability. I'm moving from 'this is a medium-term risk to manage' to 'this is a 5-year urgent priority.' Geographic diversification of semiconductor manufacturing isn't optional—it's a prerequisite for maintaining the global economy through the period of maximum US-China tension. The investment required ($500B+ globally over 10 years) is large but the cost of failure (global depression, loss of technological edge) is orders of magnitude larger. Export controls should continue but with realistic expectations: they slow China by 3-5 years, not permanently. The end state is a bifurcated semiconductor supply chain—a US/allied ecosystem and a Chinese ecosystem—with Taiwan's role diminishing as both sides build alternatives. That transition period (2025-2035) is when the risk of miscalculation is highest.

perspectives.name: Geopolitical Analyst
perspectives.role: Director at a leading geopolitical risk consultancy, advises Fortune 100 boards
perspectives.initial_position: The thesis makes compelling military arguments but overweights the kinetic scenario and underweights the economic warfare dimension that's already underway. US-China competition is primarily being fought through investment restrictions, technology controls, supply chain weaponization, and institutional influence—not carrier deployments. The carrier math matters, but it matters most as a backdrop that enables escalating economic warfare without triggering actual conflict. China's real strategy isn't to invade Taiwan; it's to make the cost of defending Taiwan so high that the US quietly de-prioritizes it.
key_threats: Economic decoupling is accelerating faster than most corporate boards recognize. US-China bilateral trade peaked in 2022 and is declining. Investment screening (CFIUS, EU Foreign Subsidies Regulation) is expanding from security-adjacent to economy-wide. Companies with significant China exposure face regulatory risk that isn't priced into their valuations.

Information warfare and influence operations are the underappreciated dimension. TikTok, Confucius Institutes, Belt and Road diplomatic leverage—China's strategy is to shape the information environment so that US allies question whether defending Taiwan is worth the cost. This isn't hypothetical; poll data shows declining support for Taiwan defense in European publics.

The 'busy elsewhere' strategy is working. US attention and resources diverted to Ukraine, the Middle East, and now potential tensions in other regions reduce bandwidth for Indo-Pacific strategy. China has increased military exercises around Taiwan during every major US distraction. They're testing response times and political willingness, not military capability.
key_moves: Advise corporate clients to scenario-plan for three levels of decoupling: gradual (current trajectory), accelerated (Taiwan crisis triggers full technology separation), and reversal (new diplomatic framework reduces tensions). Most companies are only planning for scenario 1. The probability of scenario 2 within 5 years is 20-25%.

Build a China Exposure Index for investment portfolios. Revenue from China, suppliers in China, IP licensed to Chinese entities, employees in China—aggregate the total exposure and model the impact of each decoupling scenario. Most investors would be shocked by their indirect exposure.

Position for the 'Cold War premium'—sustained higher defense spending, permanent supply chain costs, and technology bifurcation that raises costs for every global company. This isn't a temporary geopolitical risk; it's a structural cost increase that needs to be priced into every DCF model.
blind_spots: I advise companies to de-risk from China, which is the safe recommendation. But the contrarian view has merit: economic interdependence is a stabilizer. If decoupling proceeds too far, both sides lose the economic incentive to avoid conflict. My de-risking advice, multiplied across thousands of companies, might actually INCREASE the probability of conflict by removing the economic mutual hostage situation.

I model state actors rationally. But the most dangerous scenarios involve miscalculation under pressure—an accidental collision in the South China Sea, a cyber operation that escalates beyond intent, or domestic political pressure that forces action neither side wants. My risk models don't capture these 'fat tail' scenarios well enough.
perspectives.revised_position: After this debate, I'm revising my probability of a direct US-China military confrontation (not necessarily over Taiwan) from 10% to 15% over the next 10 years. More importantly, I'm raising my probability of accelerated economic decoupling to 40% over 5 years. The carrier math makes the military dimension real, but the economic warfare is the main event. Companies should plan for a world where US-China economic engagement is 50% of current levels by 2030—not because of conflict but because of policy-driven decoupling. The investment implications: defense sector is obvious, but the bigger opportunity is companies that facilitate the rewiring—logistics, alternative supply chains, technology localization, and the professional services that help multinationals navigate a bifurcated world.

perspectives.name: Defense Industry CEO
perspectives.role: CEO of mid-cap defense contractor, $5B revenue, missile systems and electronic warfare
perspectives.initial_position: The US-China thesis is the most important driver of defense spending since the Cold War, and I don't think the market has fully priced in the duration or magnitude. This isn't a one-time supplemental appropriation—it's a generational shift in defense budgets across the US, Japan, Australia, and Europe. NATO's 2% GDP target becomes 2.5%. Japan is doubling defense spending. Australia's AUKUS commitment alone is $368B. Add it up: $2T+ in incremental global defense spending over the next decade. My order book is the fullest it's been in 40 years, and the growth is structural, not cyclical.
key_threats: Munitions stockpile depletion is the crisis hiding in plain sight. The US sent 1M+ 155mm artillery rounds to Ukraine and drew down Javelin, Stinger, and ATACMS stocks. Replenishment takes 3-5 years for complex systems. If a Taiwan scenario occurred tomorrow, we'd run through precision-guided munitions in weeks. The production capacity isn't there.

Workforce constraints mirror the broader economy. My factories need 5,000 additional skilled workers to meet current orders. Clearance requirements eliminate 30% of applicants. Training takes 12-18 months. I'm competing with reshoring factories for the same machinists and electricians. The defense industrial base workforce is aging and insufficient.

Supply chain fragility in defense is worse than commercial because of security classification requirements. Critical components—specialty alloys, microelectronics, rocket propellant chemistry—have single-source suppliers, some in allied countries with their own capacity constraints. A Taiwan crisis would disrupt the supply chains we need to fight it.
key_moves: Triple investment in autonomous and unmanned systems. The carrier math problem is partially solvable through mass: 1,000 autonomous drones cost less than one fighter jet and create targeting saturation that overwhelms air defenses. The paradigm shift from manned platforms to unmanned mass is the single biggest opportunity in defense.

Build a munitions surge capacity. The current business model optimizes for peacetime efficiency. We need to build (and be paid to maintain) warm production lines that can surge 5-10x in crisis. Congress needs to fund 'capacity, not just units'—paying for the ability to produce, not just current production.

Invest in electronic warfare and cyber capabilities. The next conflict starts in the electromagnetic spectrum and cyberspace before any missile fires. EW systems that can jam, spoof, and blind adversary sensors are the highest-value investment per dollar in the current threat environment.
blind_spots: My business benefits directly from threat inflation. Every 'China is about to invade Taiwan' headline drives defense spending that flows to my bottom line. I should be deeply skeptical of my own threat assessment because my incentives are misaligned. The contrarian view: diplomatic breakthrough, economic realism, or leadership change in either country could significantly reduce tensions and my order book.

The assumption that more defense spending solves the problem might be wrong. The US outspends China 3:1 in absolute defense spending and the gap is narrowing not because of spending but because of geographic advantage, focused investment, and faster procurement cycles. We might be spending more to get less because our procurement system is broken, not underfunded.
perspectives.revised_position: The US-China thesis supports $2T+ in incremental global defense spending over the next decade, and my company is positioning to capture 3-5% of that. I'm investing $500M in autonomous systems, electronic warfare, and production capacity expansion over the next 3 years. The carrier math makes my investment thesis—spend more on distributed, autonomous, survivable capabilities—not just profitable but strategically correct. But I'm also hedging: if a diplomatic framework emerges that reduces tensions, defense spending could plateau rather than grow. I'm building capabilities that have commercial applications (autonomous systems, cybersecurity, advanced manufacturing) so the business survives a peace dividend. The base case, though, is that this is a 20-year spending cycle, not a 5-year bump. Position accordingly.

consensus: The carrier deployment math is real and constrains every US strategic commitment—this is the most under-discussed constraint in American foreign policy
China's strategy is working: keeping the US busy elsewhere while building capability advantage in the Pacific
Taiwan semiconductor concentration is an existential vulnerability for the global economy—geographic diversification is a prerequisite for stability
This is a multi-decade competition, not a crisis to be resolved—investment horizons should reflect 15-25 year structural change
Economic warfare (decoupling, technology controls, investment restrictions) is the primary battlefield, with military posture as the enabling backdrop
disagreements: Probability of kinetic conflict: Pentagon Strategist sees 2026-2030 as maximum danger period; Geopolitical Analyst puts 15% over 10 years; Defense CEO focuses on preparation regardless of probability
Primary dimension: Pentagon Strategist focuses on military capability; Semiconductor Executive on supply chain; Geopolitical Analyst on economic warfare; Defense CEO on spending implications

Resolution path: Geopolitical Analyst believes economic interdependence is a stabilizer worth preserving; Pentagon Strategist sees strategic clarity as the path to deterrence; Semiconductor Executive sees technological decoupling as inevitable

Is more spending the answer? Pentagon Strategist and Defense CEO say yes (distributed capabilities); Geopolitical Analyst says the economic and diplomatic tools matter more; Semiconductor Executive says supply chain resilience is the real investment
synthesis.key_insight: The debate reveals that the US-China rivalry is not one competition but three running simultaneously: a military balance of power (carrier math, missile ranges, force projection), an economic decoupling (trade reorientation, investment restrictions, technology controls), and a supply chain rewiring (semiconductor diversification, critical mineral access, industrial base reconstruction). Most analysis focuses on one dimension. The real strategic challenge—and investment opportunity—is in the interaction effects: military posture enables economic coercion, economic decoupling changes military calculations, and supply chain geography determines who has the manufacturing base to sustain a protracted competition. The companies and countries that solve the interaction problem—building military deterrence while maintaining enough economic engagement to prevent miscalculation while diversifying supply chains away from adversary control—will define the next quarter century.
